body.p: The purpose of this activity is to show you how a simple random sample produces a sample that is not subject to any bias and is thus representative of the population from which it was selected. Also, we'll see how a nonrandom sample can produce some sources of bias.
Consider the population of all students at a large university taking introductory statistics courses (1,129 students taking statistics for business, social sciences, or natural sciences).

Suppose we are interested in the values of four specific variables for this population: handedness (right-handed or left-handed), sex, SAT Verbal score, and age. If we were unable to determine the values of those variables for the entire population, we may be able to take a random sample from that population, and use the sample summaries as estimates for population summaries. Would the random sample provide unbiased estimates for the population values?

Next, what if instead of taking a random sample, we sampled the 192 students who happen to be enrolled in the business statistics course? First we will intuit, then check, if they would be a representative sample with respect to each of the four variables: handedness, sex, SAT Verbal score, and age. It may be helpful for you to know that, at this university, all students have comparable options in terms of when they take introductory statistics. You should also know that women, on the whole, tend to do somewhat better than men on the verbal portion of the SAT, and that business is a major that tends to interest males more than females.
To summarize the goals for this activity, we will:
Part A. Verify that the distributions of the variables handedness, sex, SAT Verbal score, and age are roughly the same for the random sample as they are for the population.

Part B. Intuit whether the distributions of each of the four variables in the (nonrandom) sample of business students would be roughly the same as those for the population, or whether there is a reason to expect any of them to be biased.

Part C. Check our intuition by comparing the distributions of each of the four variables for the sample of business students with those for the population, and determine whether they are roughly the same or if the sample values for any of the variables appear to be biased.

Our dataset contains data on the entire population of 1,129 students, which includes students taking introductory statistics who are majoring in the natural and social sciences, as well as for business majors.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To open R with the dataset preloaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in R.
The data have been loaded into the data frame "population". Enter the command population to see the data. The variables in the data frame are Course, Handed, Sex, Verbal, Age.
The variables are defined as follows:

ul.li: Course: natural science, social science, or business
Handed: righthanded or lefthanded
Sex: female or male
Verbal: SAT Verbal scores up to 800
Age: in years

alternative.p: First, we will take a simple random sample of the data. For the sake of consistency, we will make the random sample the same size (192) as the nonrandom sample of business statistics students that will be examined later.
To do this in R, copy the following command:

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To open this file in StatCrunch you must first right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Next click hereto open StatCrunch in a separate window and login using your username and password.

ul.li: Click on the link “Open StatCrunch” at the top of the My StatCrunch page.
To open the data set select the “My computer” link under Load a data set from box on the left side of the page.
Select the "Browse" or “Choose File” (depending on which browser you're using and select the data set you downloaded
Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on “Load File”

alternative.p: The dataset includes the following variables:

ul.li: Course: natural science, social science, or business
Handed: right-handed or left-handed
Sex: female or male
Verbal: SAT Verbal scores up to 800
Age: in years

alternative.p: First, we will take a simple random sample of the data. For the sake of consistency, we will make the random sample the same size (192) as the nonrandom sample of business statistics students that will be examined later.
To do this in StatCrunch:

ul.li: Choose: Data – Sample Columns
Select: Handed, Sex, Verbal and Age
Sample size: 192
Check: Sample all columns at one time
Store samples: Split across columns
Press: Sample Columns

alternative.p: Note that four columns are added called: Sample(Handed), Sample(Sex), Sample(Verbal) and Sample(Age)

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To open Minitab with the population data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Minitab. Note: you will likely see a dialog box appear that says "A copy of the content of this file will be added to the current project"—just click "OK."
The dataset includes the following variables:

ul.li: Course: natural science, social science, or business
Handed: right-handed or left-handed
Sex: female or male
Verbal: SAT Verbal scores up to 800
Age: in years

alternative.p: First, we will take a simple random sample of the data. For the sake of consistency, we will make the random sample the same size (192) as the nonrandom sample of business statistics students that will be examined later.
To do this in Minitab:

ul.li: Choose: Calc → Random Data → Sample From Columns.
Next to "Number of rows to sample," enter "192" to indicate the requested size of the random sample.
Under "From columns:" enter "Handed Sex Verbal Age" (or double-click on each variable in the left panel) to indicate the variables we are sampling.
Under "Store samples in:" type "HandedRandom SexRandom VerbalRandom AgeRandom".
Click "OK."

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.
The dataset includes the following variables:

ul.li: Course: natural science, social science, or business
Handed: right-handed or left-handed
Sex: female or male
Verbal: SAT Verbal scores up to 800
Age: in years

alternative.p: First, we will take a simple random sample of the data. For the sake of consistency, we will make the random sample the same size (192) as the nonrandom sample of business statistics students that will be examined later.
To do this in Excel:

ul.li: Pick five empty columns in your Excel worksheet and label them RandomNumber, HandedRandom, SexRandom, VerbalRandom, and AgeRandom. You can widen each column if needed by dragging your mouse while your cursor is directly in the middle of two columns at the top of the Excel sheet.

In the RandomNumber column, type this formula in row 2: =RAND(). Then copy and paste it in all cells in the column from row 3 down to row 1,130. This generates a random number in each cell of the column. You can do this by right-clicking the cell in the row 2 and selecting copy, highlighting the relevant rows and then using another right-click to select paste. This generates a random number in each cell of the column.
Select the entire column of random numbers that you just created, right-click on the column and choose Copy, and then right-click on the column again and choose Paste Special.
In the pop-up window, choose Values under Paste, and click OK.
Type Control-A twice to select all of the data in the worksheet, and then choose Sort & Filter → Custom Sort from the Editing group in the Home tab.
In the pop-up window, make sure that My data has headers is checked and then choose RandomNumber from the pull-down menu next to Sort by. Click OK.

Now select all of the data in rows 2-193 under the columns that contain the original variables (Handed, Sex, Verbal, Age), and copy and paste those data to the new columns you created (HandedRandom, SexRandom, VerbalRandom, and AgeRandom).

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: Important Note! TI 83/84 calculators do not have the built-in capability to create a table of counts and percentages or to construct a pie chart. Thus, for this activity, we suggest trying one of the other technologies available in OLI Statistics. R is an excellent statistical package that is free to download and that is available for both Windows and Mac OS X.
If you want to continue with the TI Calculator, you can produce a table of counts and percentages by hand using your TI to help. You can download an app that will allow you to construct a pie chart.

To open a group of lists with the survey data loaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and send it to your calculator. For instructions on how to connect your calculator to your computer and transfer a file, click here.
In order to see all of the lists in table format on your TI calculator, you'll need to create 2 extra lists called VERBL and AGE. For a reminder of how to do this, click here.
The original dataset includes the following variables:

ul.li: Course: natural science, social science, or business
Handed: right-handed or left-handed
Sex: female or male
Verbal: SAT Verbal scores up to 800
Age: in years

alternative.p: Since the maximum list size on the TI 83/84 graphing calculator is 999, it is difficult to store the entire dataset on the TI (you could do it by splitting it into a couple of lists but it’s not pretty). So, we’ve given you a simple random sample of the data and will also give you the information you need about the population to compare the samples you have in the lists to the population (which you don’t have in the lists). For the sake of consistency, we made the random sample the same size (192) as the nonrandom sample of business statistics students that will be examined later.
On the TI calculator, the dataset is displayed in lists L1-L6, VERBL, and AGE:

ul.li: L1: Random sample Handed (1 = right-handed, 2 = left-handed)
L2: Random sample Sex (1 = female, 2 = male)
L3: Random sample Verbal SAT
L4: Random sample Age
L5: Business Handed (1 = right-handed, 2 = left-handed)
L6: Business Sex (1 = female, 2 = male)
VERBL: Business Verbal SAT (-9999 represents missing data)
AGE: Business Age

body.p: Part A. Now we will determine whether the four variables' behavior for the random sample is comparable to their behavior for the population.

ul.li: Step 1. To compare the proportion of right-handed students in the sample to those in the population, create 2 pie charts, or if using the R statpackage 2 side-by-side bar graphs one for handedness in the population and one for handedness in the random sample.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To create bar charts do this in R, copy the commands below:
To create pie charts do this in R, copy the entire command below:
Note: When using R and getting it to display 2 graphs at once requires the "par" command, which tells R to display the next 2 graphs together.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in StatCrunch:

ul.li: Choose: Graphics – Pie Chart – with data
Select the columns Handed and Sample(Handed)
Press Next three times
Columns per page: 2
Press: Create Graph!

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in Minitab:

ul.li: Choose Graph → Pie Chart
Under "Categorical variables" enter "Handed HandedRandom"
Click on "Labels," choose the "Slice Labels" tab, and check "Percent"
Click "OK," then click "OK" again.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in Excel, we must first construct a table of counts. Let's do this for the variable "Handed" first:

ul.li: Click on the cell with the variable label Handed.
Click on the PivotTable button in theTables group in the Insert tab.
Click OK.
Excel will create a new worksheet with a blank table. We have to tell Excel how to construct the table:
You should see a window titled PivotTable Field List with a list of our variables.
Check the box next to Handed.
Now drag the Handed item to the table where it says Drop Value Fields Here.

alternative.p: You should now have a table that shows the number of each type of data entry: "left," "right," and a grand total. This is the count of each of these entries. Now we can create a pie chart for the "Handed" variable:

ul.li: Click on one of the cells in your table and then click the PivotChart button in the Tools group on the Analyze (PivotTable Tools) tab.
In the Insert Chart window that appears, choose the first pie chart option and click OK.
To label the sections of the pie, right click the pie and choose Add Data Labels from the pop-up menu.

To see percentages as well as absolute values, right-click one of the data labels and choose Format Data Labels. Then make sure that Label Options is selected on the left and check the box next to Percentage and click Close.

alternative.p: Now repeat this process to create a table of counts and a pie chart for the variable "HandedRandom."

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: First, sort the list that contains the coded data for the random sample Handed variable in ascending order:

ul.li: Choose STAT/EDIT/2:SortA(
You should see:
Before pressing ENTER, choose L1 (2ND/1) since that is the list that we want to sort.
Press the right parenthesis, then ENTER.
You should see:
Check out the sorted list by choosing STAT/EDIT/1:Edit....

alternative.p: Count the number of values for each category in column 1 (1 = right, 2 = left).
The page Module 1 One Categorical Variable (1 of 3) describes how to create a table with counts and percentages.

While the TI Calculator does not have the built-in capability to create a pie chart, you can download an app for your calculator that will do this. It is called CellSheet App and is a free download from the TI website. Note that some TI calculators have the CellSheet App preloaded—choose APPS on your TI to see if CellSheet App is already loaded on your calculator.
The TI website also includes instructions for downloading apps to your TI and an example exercise that shows how to construct a pie chart.
Once you have CellSheet App installed, use it to create a pie chart on the TI:

ul.li: Press APPS.
Choose Celsheet.
Press any key twice to get to the spreadsheet screen.
Press GRAPH to access the CellSheet menu.
Choose 1:File
Choose 3:New
Name the spreadsheet and press ENTER.
Press ENTER again.

Now enter the labels for the pie chart in row 1, starting in column A.
Use the arrow keys to position the cursor in A1.
Choose A-LOCK (2ND/ALPHA).
Press " (found over the + key), then continue pressing the letters for a name for the first category (right). Press ENTER when finished.
Your cursor should be in A2.
Enter the percentage for the first category (161/192 = 0.8385).
Repeat for each category of the categorical variable (in this case name = left and percentage = 31/192 = 0.1615).
You should see:
Choose the Menu by pressing GRAPH.
Choose 4:Charts.
Choose 7:Pie.
You should see:

For Categories: enter the range for the category labels, for example, A1:C1
Press ALPHA/MATH for the A, then press the number 1.
Press ALPHA/. for the : (Press ALPHA and a decimal point to get a colon).
Press ALPHA/APPS for the B, then press the number 1.
Press ENTER or the down arrow to move to the next line.
For Series: enter the range of the percentages of each category, or A2:C2.
Choose percent by highlighting Percent and pressing ENTER.
Enter a Title:. Alpha-lock is automatically on, so press up to 10 letters for a title.
You should see:
Choose DRAW and press ENTER.
Choose TRACE and use arrows to investigate the different categories for the pie chart.
Record your data for the Handed variable in the random sample.

Now, produce a pie chart for the Handed variable in the population using the fact that there are 979 right-handed students and 150 left-handed students in the population (i.e., calculate the new percentages for Right and Left handedness). NOTE: RECORD THESE DATA for the population, since you’ll need them to compare to the sample of business students below.

body.p: Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of the population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the first Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answer.)

ul.li: Step 2. To compare the proportion of female students in the sample to the proportion in the population, create 2 pie charts, one for sex in the population and one for sex in the random sample.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: Use the commands above, but replace "$Handed" with "$Sex" and "left" with "female" and "right" with "male".
Below is the code with the changes we suggested above in case you want to check your command.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: Follow the same StatCrunch instructions as before, changing the variables to Sex and Sample(Sex).

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: Follow the same Minitab instructions as before, changing the variables to Sex and SexRandom.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: Follow the same Excel instructions as before, changing the variables to Sex and SexRandom.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: Follow the same TI graphing calculator instructions as before, changing the variables to Sex (female/male) in the population and Sex (1 = female, 2 = male) in the random sample. For Sex in the population, use the fact that there are 701 females and 428 males in the population. For sex in the random sample, use the data in L2.
NOTE: RECORD THESE DATA for the population, since you’ll need them to compare to the sample of business students below.

body.p: Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the first Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

ul.li: Step 3. Create 2 descriptive statistics summary tables—one for SAT Verbal score in the population and one for SAT Verbal score in the sample

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in R, copy the following commands:

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To ask StatCrunch for descriptive statistics for SAT Verbal scores in the population and the sample:

ul.li: Choose Stat – Summary Stats – Columns
Select Columns: Verbal, Sample(Verbal)
Press: Calculate

alternative.p: Note that with StatCrunch we have produced all of the required information in a single table.

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To ask Minitab for descriptive statistics for SAT Verbal scores in the population and the sample:

ul.li: Choose Stat → Basic Statistics → Display Descriptive Statistics.
Under "Variables," enter "Verbal Verbalrandom".
Click "OK."

alternative.p: You will see 2 rows of numbers in the descriptive statistics. The one labeled "Verbal" contains the values for the population, and the one labeled "VerbalRandom" contains the values for the random sample.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: Let's do this for "Verbal" first:

ul.li: Pick an empty cell, and type min.
Then, in the next cell to the right, type =min(D2:D1130).
In the cell undermin, type Q1.
Then, in the next cell to the right, type =quartile(D2:D1130,1).
In the cell underQ1, type Median.
Then, in the next cell to the right, type =median(D2:D1130).
In the cell underMedian, type Mean.
Then, in the next cell to the right, type =average(D2:D1130).
In the cell underMean, type Q3.
Then, in the next cell to the right, type =quartile(D2:D1130,3).
In the cell underQ3, type Max.
Then, in the next cell to the right, type =max(D2:D1130).

alternative.p: Now use the same instructions, but change the data range as appropriate, to create a five-number summary table for "VerbalRandom."

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: NOTE: Verify that all missing values (signified by -9999) have been removed from the sample data (L3).
We’ve calculated the population parameters:

Remember that
x ¯
represents the population mean (μ) when the data in the list are population data.
To calculate descriptive statistics for SAT Verbal score in the sample:

ul.li: Choose STAT/CALC/1:1-Var Stats. Since the random sample SAT Verbal score data are in L3, enter 2ND/3 to choose L3 for List.
Leave FreqList blank.
Use the down arrow to highlight Calculate and press ENTER.

alternative.p: Note: Once the missing values are deleted, we only have information on SAT Verbal Score for 998 individuals in the population (out of 1,129 total individuals).

body.p: Since SAT scores tend to follow a normal (symmetric) distribution, you can focus on means to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample mean SAT Verbal score comes within about 10 points of the population mean. Does it? (Use the text box in the first Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

ul.li: Step 4. Create 2 more descriptive statistics summary tables—one for age in the population and one for age in the sample.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in R, just substitute "$Age" for "$Verbal" in the 2 commands above.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To ask StatCrunch for descriptive statistics for age in the population and the sample, follow the same StatCrunch instructions as above, changing the variables to: Age and Sample(Age)

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To ask Minitab for descriptive statistics for age in the population and the sample, follow the same Minitab instructions as above, changing the variables to: Age Agerandom.
You will see 2 rows of numbers in the descriptive statistics. The one labeled "Age" contains the values for the population, and the one labeled "AgeRandom" contains the values for the random sample.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in Excel, use the instructions above, but with the variables "Age" and "AgeRandom."

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: To calculate descriptive statistics for age in the sample, follow the same TI instructions as above, changing the list to L4 (age in the random sample).

body.p: Since Age tends to follow a right-skewed distribution, you should focus on medians to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample median age comes within about .5 years of the population median. Does it?

Part B. Intuit whether the distributions of each of the four variables in the (nonrandom) sample of business students would be roughly the same as those for the population, or whether there is a reason to expect any of them to be biased.

Part C. Check our intuition by comparing the distributions of each of the four variables for the sample of business students with those for the population, and determine whether they are roughly the same or if the sample values for any of the variables appear to be biased.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To do this with R, execute the following command in R:

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in StatCrunch

ul.li: Data – Sort columns
Select: Handed, Sex, Verbal, Age
Sort by: Course
Press: Sort Columns

alternative.p: Note that after sorting all of the Business students are now listed first. The corresponding variables are now called Sort(Handed), Sort(Sex), Sort(Verbal) and Sort(Age).

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in Minitab,

ul.li: Choose Data → Unstack Columns.
Next to "Unstack the data in:" enter: "Handed Sex Verbal Age."
Next to "Using subscripts in:" type "Course."
Choose the option: "After last column in use."
Click "OK."

alternative.p: The responses for the (nonrandom) sample of students in the business statistics course will now appear in the columns "Handed_Business," "Sex_Business," "Verbal_Business" and "Age_Business" at the end of the worksheet.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in Excel, we'll first sort the original data using the variable "Course," and then copy the data for "Business" into four new columns:

ul.li: Type Control-A twice to select all of the data in the worksheet, and then choose Sort & Filter → Custom Sort from the Editing group in the Home tab.
In the pop-up window, make sure that My data has headers is checked and then choose Course from the pull-down menu next to Sort by. Click OK.
Now pick four empty columns and label them Handed_Business, Sex_Business, Verbal_Business, and Age_Business
Finally, copy the data for our four original variables (Handed, Sex, Verbal, and Age) from the rows where the course is Business and paste them in the new columns.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: The responses for the (nonrandom) sample of students in the business statistics course are stored in L5 (Handed), L6 (Sex), VERBL (SAT Verbal score), and AGE (Age) lists.

body.p: Next, we explore whether the four variables' behavior for the (nonrandom) sample of business statistics students is comparable to their behavior for the population:

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in R, you will just use the commands from above in parts A and B, but replace the variable "random_sample" with "business". In the pie chart commands, replace "Random Sample" with "Business Students".

Step 1. To compare the proportion of right-handed students in the sample to those in the population, create 2 pie charts, one for handedness in the population and one for handedness in the sample of business statistics students.

ul.li: Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of the population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

alternative.p: Step 2. To compare the proportion of female students in the sample to the proportion in the population, create 2 pie charts (using the instructions above), one for sex in the population and one for sex in the sample of business statistics students.

ul.li: Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of the population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

alternative.p: Step 3. Create 2 tables of descriptive statistics (using the instructions above)—one for SAT Verbal score in the population and one for SAT Verbal score in the sample of business statistics students.

ul.li: Since SAT scores tend to follow a normal (symmetric) distribution, you can focus on means to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample mean SAT Verbal score comes within about 10 points of the population mean. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

alternative.p: Step 4. Create 2 tables of descriptive statistics (using the instructions above)—one for age in the population and one for age in the sample of business statistics students.

ul.li: Since age tends to follow a right-skewed distribution, you should focus on medians to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample median age comes within about .5 years of the population median. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: Step 1. To compare the proportion of right-handed students in the sample to those in the population, create 2 pie charts, one for handedness in the population and one for handedness in the sample of business statistics students.
To do this in StatCrunch:

ul.li: Choose: Graphics – Pie Chart – with data
Select the column Handed
Press Create Graph!

alternative.p: Record results and then repeat as follows:

ul.li: Choose: Graphics – Pie Chart – with data
Select the column Sort(Handed)
Where: row < 193
Press Create Graph!

alternative.p: Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of the population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

Step 2. To compare the proportion of female students in the sample to the proportion in the population, create 2 pie charts (using the instructions above), one for sex in the population and one for sex in the sample of business statistics students.

Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of the population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)
Step 3. Create 2 tables of descriptive statistics (using the instructions above)—one for SAT Verbal score in the population and one for SAT Verbal score in the sample of business statistics students.
To do this in StatCrunch:

ul.li: Choose: Stat - Summary Stats - Columns
Select the column Verbal
Press Calculate

alternative.p: Record results and then repeat as follows:

ul.li: Choose: Stat - Summary Stats - Columns
Select the column Sort(Verbal)
Where: row < 193
Press Calculate

alternative.p: Since SAT scores tend to follow a normal (symmetric) distribution, you can focus on means to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample mean SAT Verbal score comes within about 10 points of the population mean. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)
Step 4. Create 2 tables of descriptive statistics (using the instructions above)—one for age in the population and one for age in the sample of business statistics students.

Since age tends to follow a right-skewed distribution, you should focus on medians to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample median age comes within about .5 years of the population median. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in Minitab:

ul.li: Choose Graph → Pie Chart.
Under "Categorical variables" enter: Handed 'Handed_Business'.
Click on "Labels", choose the "Slice Labels" tab, and check "Percent."
>Click OK.
Click OK again.

alternative.p: Step 1. To compare the proportion of right-handed students in the sample to those in the population, create 2 pie charts, one for handedness in the population and one for handedness in the sample of business statistics students:

Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of the population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

Step 2. To compare the proportion of female students in the sample to the proportion in the population, create 2 pie charts (using the instructions above), one for sex in the population and one for sex in the sample of business statistics students.

Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of the population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)
Step 3. Create 2 tables of descriptive statistics (using the instructions above)—one for SAT Verbal score in the population and one for SAT Verbal score in the sample of business statistics students.

Since SAT scores tend to follow a normal (symmetric) distribution, you can focus on means to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample mean SAT Verbal score comes within about 10 points of the population mean. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)
Step 4. Create 2 tables of descriptive statistics (using the instructions above)—one for age in the population and one for age in the sample of business statistics students.

Since age tends to follow a right-skewed distribution, you should focus on medians to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample median age comes within about .5 years of the population median. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: Use the above instructions for pie charts to do this in Excel.

Step 1. To compare the proportion of right-handed students in the sample to those in the population, create 2 pie charts, one for handedness in the population and one for handedness in the sample of business statistics students:

Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of the population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

Step 2. To compare the proportion of female students in the sample to the proportion in the population, create 2 pie charts (using the instructions above), one for sex in the population and one for sex in the sample of business statistics students.

Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of the population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)
Step 3. Create 2 tables of descriptive statistics (using the instructions above)—one for SAT Verbal score in the population and one for SAT Verbal score in the sample of business statistics students.

Since SAT scores tend to follow a normal (symmetric) distribution, you can focus on means to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample mean SAT Verbal score comes within about 10 points of the population mean. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)
Step 4. Create 2 tables of descriptive statistics (using the instructions above)—one for age in the population and one for age in the sample of business statistics students.

Since age tends to follow a right-skewed distribution, you should focus on medians to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample median age comes within about .5 years of the population median. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: Step 1. To compare the proportion of right-handed students in the sample to those in the population, create 2 pie charts, one for handedness in the population and one for handedness in the sample of business statistics students (L5):
You can produce a table of counts or percentages by hand for the sample of business students' handedness data (L5) using your TI to help. Follow the instructions above, adjusting accordingly.

Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of the population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

Step 2. To compare the proportion of female students in the sample to the proportion in the population, create a pie chart (using the instructions above), for sex in the sample of business statistics students (L6).
Compare this to the data/pie chart that you recorded above for the age variable in the population. Remember that there are 701 females and 428 males in the population.

Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample proportion comes within about 5% of the population proportion. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)

Step 3. Create 2 tables of descriptive statistics (using the instructions above)—one for SAT Verbal score in the population and one for SAT Verbal score in the sample of business statistics students (list VERBL).

NOTE: You must delete all missing values (-9999) in list VERBL before calculating descriptive statistics. Remember: To get a named list, use LIST (2ND/STAT). Choose NAMES. Then arrow down to find VERBL.
Note: Once the missing values are deleted, we only have information on SAT Verbal scores for 998 individuals in the population (out of 1,129 total individuals).

Since SAT scores tend to follow a normal (symmetric) distribution, you can focus on means to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample mean SAT Verbal Score comes within about 10 points of the population mean. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)
Step 4. Create 2 tables of descriptive statistics (using the instructions above)one for age in the population and one for age in the sample of business statistics students (list AGE).

Since age tends to follow a right-skewed distribution, you should focus on medians to make a comparison. Consider the distributions to be comparable if the sample median age comes within about .5 years of the population median. Does it? (Use the text box in the Learn By Doing exercise below to record your answers.)
